65 Content Marketing Stats Every Marketer Needs to Know

Written by Brian Dean

Last updated Dec. 27, 2024

This is a list of up-to-date content marketing statistics.

On this page we’ve compiled statistics on:

  • Blogging
  • Video content
  • Social media marketing
  • Podcasting
  • Emerging trends
  • Lots more

Let’s get right into the stats!

Contents

1. Blogging Statistics
2. Video Content Marketing Statistics
3. Podcast Statistics
4. Social Media Marketing Statistics
5. B2B Content Marketing Statistics
6. B2C Content Marketing Statistics
7. Content Marketing Benchmarks & Trends

01. Blogging Statistics

Despite the rise of video and social media, blogging and SEO are the two foundations of any content strategy in 2024. And there’s data to back this up. As you’re about to see, pro marketers put the lion’s share of their time and budget into creating content designed to rank in Google. The question is: how well does blogging work in 2024? Let’s find out.

  1. Blogs rank as the most widely used content type for demand generation purposes among content marketers (Content Marketing Institute)
  2. The average blog post contains 1427 words (Orbit Media)
  3. It takes writers an average of 3 hours and 51 minutes to write a blog post (Orbit Media)
  4. Bloggers who spend at least 6 hours creating each post report “strong” content marketing results in 35% of the time, compared to 21% in the 2-3 hours range (Orbit Media)
  5. Blog posts with 7 or more images generated 55% more backlinks in comparison to posts without images (Semrush)

02. Video Content Marketing Statistics

Online video is exploding right now. As you’re about to see, most of this growth is on YouTube. But other platforms (like Facebook and Instagram) are catching up fast.

  1. More than half of marketers use social video videos (77%), branded stories (61%), and how-to videos (59%) in their video marketing initiatives (Content Marketing Institute)
  2. 87% of marketers say video marketing has helped them increase website traffic (Wyzowl)
  3. 84% of marketers claim that results from videos meet or exceed their expectations (Content Marketing Institute)
  4. Marketers report that YouTube (85%), LinkedIn (84%), and Facebook (67%) are the top 3 social platforms to distribute video content (Content Marketing Institute)
  5. 89% of consumers say they would like more video content from brands in 2024 (Wyzowl)
  6. 44% of consumers said that a short video was their favorite medium to learn about a product or service (Wyzowl)
  7. The average retention rate for videos under 1 minute long is 66% (Vidyard)
  8. Globally, YouTube’s Android app users spend over 10 trillion minutes per month watching videos. (DataReportal)

03. Podcast Statistics

Now it’s time to cover content marketing statistics that are focused on podcasts. What’s interesting about podcasts is how quickly they went from a niche form of content to a mainstream medium. These podcasting statistics show just how big this platform is… and how it has the potential to grow even more.

  1. 55% of Americans (ages 12+) listened to podcasts in the last month. That’s an estimated 135 million podcast listeners in the US (Edison Research)
  2. 59% of American ages 12-34 listened to podcasts in the past month compared to 27% among the population aged 55 and over. (Edison Research)
  3. On average, weekly podcast listeners listened to 8.3 podcast episodes in the past week (Edison Research)
  4. The average time spent per day with podcasts among US users amounted to 28 minutes in 2024 (eMarketer)
  5. Spotify accounts for 31.8% of podcast listeners in the US (eMarketer)
  6. Spotify, iHeartRadio, and Apple Podcasts combined account for 77.4% of US podcast listeners (eMarketer)
  7. Podcasts now account for 26.4% of total time spent with digital audio (eMarketer)
  8. Millennials currently account for 32.7% of podcast consumers in the US, totaling 44.3 million individuals, with Generation Z following closely at 28.9% (39.1 million people) (eMarketer)
  9. US podcast ad spending is estimated to hit $3.25 billion in 2024 and $3.98 billion by 2025 (eMarketer)

04. Social Media Marketing Statistics

Social media and content marketing go hand in hand. First of all, a lot of the content that people produce is specifically for social media platforms, like Facebook and YouTube. Also, social media is an important distribution channel for content that people publish on their own websites. Now it’s time to see what the data says about how social media marketing impacts content marketing.

  1. On average, internet users worldwide spend 2 hours and 20 minutes a day on social media (DataReportal)
  2. Facebook is still the top social media platform used by marketers, followed by Instagram and LinkedIn (Statista)
  3. A study conducted by Rival IQ found that the median engagement rate on Instagram is 0.43%, compared to only 0.063% on Facebook and 0.029% on X/Twitter (Rival IQ)
  4. The best time to post on Facebook is Wednesdays at 11 am or 1 pm (Sprout Social)
  5. The best times to post on Instagram are Wednesdays at 11 am or Fridays at 11 am (Sprout Social)
  6. The best times to post on X/Twitter are Wednesdays at 9 am and Fridays at 10 am (Sprout Social)
  7. The best times to post on LinkedIn are Tuesdays and Wednesdays at 10 am (Sprout Social)
  8. As of April 2024, here are the number of global active users by each of the major social channels: Facebook (3.065 billion), YouTube (2.504 billion), Instagram (2 billion), TikTok (1.582 billion), Snapchat (800 million), X/Twitter (611 million), Pinterest (498 million) (Statista)
  9. Content containing 1,000-2,000 words generates an average of 56.1% more shares on social media compared to content with fewer than 1,000 words (Backlinko)
  10. 1.3% of all articles published online receive 75% of all social shares (Backlinko)

05. B2B Content Marketing Statistics

If you’re in B2B, you already know that you need to approach content marketing differently than in B2C. And I’m not talking about pushing out tons of white papers. It’s 2024 after all!

That’s not to say that content marketing in B2B is any less effective than it used to be. You just need to create content for people who are going to consume that content (and possibly convert) at work. This list of content marketing stats focused on the B2B world gives some insight into how this plays out in the real world.

  1. 53% of B2B marketers say case studies/customer stories and videos produce the best results (Content Marketing Institute)
  2. Short articles and videos rank as the most widely used content formats among B2B marketers in the last 12 months (Content Marketing Institute)
  3. When it comes to most effective content distribution channels, more than half of B2B marketers say in-person events (56%) and webinars (51%) deliver the best results (Content Marketing Institute)
  4. The top three commonly used metrics to evaluate content performance are conversions (73%), email engagement (71%), website traffic (71%) (Content Marketing Institute)
  5. According to 84% of B2B marketers, content marketing has proven to be helpful in generating brand awareness over the past 12 months (Content Marketing Institute)
  6. Over 7 in 10 (72%) of B2B marketers claim to use generative AI tasks for content tasks (Content Marketing Institute)
  7. 51% of B2B marketers use AI tools to brainstorm new topics. Some marketers use AI to research keywords, headlines (45%) and write drafts (45%) (Content Marketing Institute)
  8. More than half (57%) of B2B marketers say “creating the right content for our audience” is a challenge. Other common challenges include creating content consistently (54%), differentiating content (54%), and optimizing for SEO (45%) (Content Marketing Institute)
  9. 93% of content on B2B sites gets zero links from other sites (Backlinko)
  10. Only 3% of content on B2B sites receive links from multiple websites (Backlinko)
  11. 2% of articles created by B2B brands result in 75% of social shares of all B2B content (Backlinko)
  12. Less than half (41%) of B2B marketers have a documented content marketing strategy (Gartner)
  13. 49% of US B2B marketers say content marketing is the most effective channel for driving revenues (eMarketer)

06. B2C Content Marketing Statistics

Now it’s time to cover a handful of B2C content marketing statistics. So if you’re in fitness, health, fashion, or other B2C industries, you’ll probably be super interested in these stats.

  1. Only 37% of B2B marketers have a documented content marketing strategy. Another 36% of respondents say they have it but it’s not documented (Content Marketing Institute)
  2. B2C content produces 9.7x more shares than content on B2B sites (Backlinko)
  3. 48% of B2C marketers claim in-person events produced the best results for their content marketing in the past 12 months, followed by short articles/posts (47%), videos (45%), and virtual events/webinars/online courses (41%) (Content Marketing Institute)
  4. The vast majority of B2C marketers used their own company websites (87%), blogs (76%), and email newsletters (68%) among owned-media platforms to distribute content in the past 12 months (Content Marketing Institute)
  5. The top 3 types of tools that B2C marketers use to manage their content: analytics tools (81%), social media publishing/analytics (72%), and email marketing software (65%) (Content Marketing Institute)
  6. In 2023, 63% of B2C marketers said they had used paid methods to distribute their content during the last 12 months. That decreased from 78% in the previous year (Content Marketing Institute)
  7. 82% of B2C content marketers report measuring content performance (Content Marketing Institute)
  8. Nearly half (49%) of B2C marketers say it’s a challenge to integrate/correlate data from multiple sources when measuring content performance (Content Marketing Institute)
  9. In 2023, 47% of B2C marketers have increased their spending on content marketing over the last 12 months (Content Marketing Institute)
  10. The top 3 paid channels that B2C marketers use as part of their content marketing strategy: social media advertising/promoted posts (88%), search engine marketing (SEM)/pay-per-click (73%), and sponsorships (55%) (Content Marketing Institute)
  11. Around one-third (31%) of B2C marketers disclosed that their organization invests 50% or more of its total marketing budget in content marketing (Content Marketing Institute)
  12. 65% of B2C marketers say they “frequently” or “always” differentiate content from their competitors (Content Marketing Institute)

07. Content Marketing Benchmarks & Trends

Let’s wrap things up with a slew of interesting stats that show how content fits into the digital marketing landscape. And where it may be heading.

  1. 38% of CMOs plan to increase content marketing budgets at their organizations in 2024 (Matter Communications)
  2. 23% of marketing professionals say content marketing had the biggest impact on their multi-channel strategy, which is behind social media (46%), email marketing (45%) and digital advertising (26%) (Ascend2)
  3. An overwhelming majority (94%) of blog posts earn zero external links (Backlinko)
  4. The average annual salary for content marketers in the US amounts to $112,000 (Content Marketing Institute)
  5. The most common challenges faced by marketers when it comes to content marketing include finding ideas for new content (16%), creating content that receives high levels of engagement (16%), creating content that attracts more website traffic (15%) (HubSpot)
  6. Articles with at least one video received 70% more traffic compared to articles without videos (Semrush)
  7. According to 83% of marketers, content marketing is the most effective strategy for demand generation (Content Marketing Institute)
  8. The top goals companies have for their content marketing efforts are brand awareness and building loyalty among existing customers (Statista)

Conclusion

I hope you learned something new from my list of content marketing statistics.

In conclusion, these content marketing statistics shed light on the evolving landscape of digital marketing.

From the increasing importance of visual content to the rise of video consumption, businesses must adapt their strategies to remain relevant and engaging to their audiences.
